title: The Easiest Ways to Wash and Scrub Potatoes For Cooking

steps.title: Start with clean hands.
steps.content: Start with clean hands. Be sure to wash your hands first using an antibacterial soap, and to rinse them well. You don't want to transfer any bacteria to your clean potatoes. Wash the potatoes just before you plan to cook and eat them. Do not wash the potatoes before storing them, as this could lead to early rot and spoilage. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the potato with cool water.
steps.content: Rinse the potato with cool water. [2] X Research source All potatoes should be washed, including organic ones, and ones you plan on peeling. Organic potatoes may be free of chemicals and pesticides, but they will still be covered with dirt and bacteria. You also want to wash potatoes that you plan on peeling. If you don't wash them first, you might end up dragging some of the bacteria or dirt onto the flesh when you go to peel them.

steps.title: Dampen the vegetable scrubber or bristled brush.
steps.content: Dampen the vegetable scrubber or bristled brush. Try to avoid using the same scrubber you use for your dishes. It may contain some soap residue, which might get onto the potato. If you don't have a vegetable scrubbing brush, find a clean sponge with a scratchy, scrubby side, and use that instead.

steps.title: Scrub the potato using a circular motion.
steps.content: Scrub the potato using a circular motion. Focus on any dirty areas as well as the eyes, where most of the dirt collects. [3] X Research source Do not use any soaps, detergents, or produce cleaners. You may not end up getting all of the residue off. Also, research has proven that a simple scrubbing is pretty effective. [4] X Research source [5] X Research source If you notice any sprouts, pull them off. Don't leave them on the potato.

steps.title: Rinse the scrubber and potato.
steps.content: Rinse the scrubber and potato. Overtime, the scrubber may start to turn off-color. If this happens, simply rinse both the scrubber and the potato under water.

steps.title: Repeat the scrubbing and rinsing until your potato is lighter than it was before.
steps.content: Repeat the scrubbing and rinsing until your potato is lighter than it was before. If you have a white dish scrubber, you can wait until it stops getting off-color. If you don't, wait until the potato is a few shades lighter. It may have splotches of different colors. That's fine.

steps.title: Pat the potato dry with a paper towel, then move onto the next one.
steps.content: Pat the potato dry with a paper towel, then move onto the next one. This can help remove any leftover dirt and bacteria. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Plan to wash your potatoes before you are ready to cook and eat them.
steps.content: Plan to wash your potatoes before you are ready to cook and eat them. Do not wash them any sooner, and certainly not before storing them. If you wash the potatoes before storing them, they may never fully dry, and start to rot.

steps.title: Find a clean, exfoliating bath glove.
steps.content: Find a clean, exfoliating bath glove. You can find them in make up shops and in the beauty section of a department store. They are usually made of a coarse, scrubby material. Make sure that the glove is new. Use it only for washing potatoes. Do not use it again to exfoliate your body.

steps.title: Wash your hands with soap and water, then put the glove on.
steps.content: Wash your hands with soap and water, then put the glove on. You will be using the glove to scrub the dirt away.

steps.title: Soak both the potato and glove under cool, running water.
steps.content: Soak both the potato and glove under cool, running water. If you are concerned about wasting water, turn the faucet off. Do not use any soap, dish detergent, or produce cleaner. If you use these, you may not get all of the residue off the potato.

steps.title: Gently massage the potato.
steps.content: Gently massage the potato. Roll and turn and tumble the potato in your hand. The glove's scrubby material will act like a vegetable scrubber, and buff the dirty away.

steps.title: Rinse the glove and the potato under cool, running water.
steps.content: Rinse the glove and the potato under cool, running water. The potato should be a little lighter in color than before. If you need to, repeat the scrubbing and rinsing process.

steps.title: Pat the potato dry with a paper towel, then move onto the next one.
steps.content: Pat the potato dry with a paper towel, then move onto the next one. Drying the potato off may also help wipe off any extra dirt and bacteria.

steps.title: Wash the glove when you are done.
steps.content: Wash the glove when you are done. If it is very dirty, add some soap, but make sure that you rinse it out completely.
